definition[0]: likely to suffer from something or be affected by something
example[0]: The magazine’s editor is open to criticism in allowing the article to be printed.
example[1]: The regulations are open to abuse by companies.
example[2]: He has left himself open to accusations of dishonesty.
definition[1]: willing to consider something new or to accept something new
example[3]: Teachers need to be open to children’s ideas.
example[4]: The committee is open to suggestions.
example[5]: The owners of the building want to sell and are open to offers.
